body:
Looks like this issue may be related to sending large payloads back to the main thread:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47692566/python-multiprocessing-apply-async-assert-left-0-assertionerror

However, sounds like that specific issue should have been resolved in Python 3.8.

How large is each image in this dataset?  If you limit the number of examples to say 10%, does the issue persist?

A smaller dataset works, I've been training on this since last month, and I just tried expanding the dataset to around 200k samples.
Each image size varies a lot, since it is a mix of .bmp and .png, 224x224 rgb images.
Will get some statistics for you, and double-check the dataset (in the past a much bigger image slipped in the dataset, but the message was different)

Just retried with an older dataset of 100k samples and works like a charm.

100k samples dataset: average image size is 120kb, for 12GB total size, and an HDF5 file generated of around 14.5GB
200k samples dataset: average image size is 116kb, for 23GB total size, and an HDF5 file never gets generated, but I expect something around 25GB

Do you have any other suggestion to check?
In the meantime I'm trying, on the same exact machine where the 200k dataset fails, to run a test with the 100k dataset. I expect it will work fine, but I want to confirm that on the same exact machine.

@carlogrisetti, have you tried setting the preprocessing parameter `'in_memory': False` for the image feature?  It may be that the system just doesn't have enough RAM to read the dataset into memory.  How much RAM does this machine have?

100k samples work fine with or without in_memory: False
200k samples does not work with or without in_memory: False

It seems it has the same exact behavior (also because the hdf5 build seems to happen in memory no matter what)

@carlogrisetti do you know at what line in Ludwig the error is coming from?  My original suspicion was that it was coming from [here](https://github.com/uber/ludwig/blob/master/ludwig/features/image_feature.py#L298), but that cannot be the case when `in_memory: False`.  Unfortunately, the provided stack traces are outside the main thread, so it's unclear what part triggered this multiprocessing pool.

I tried running ludwig train with debug set, and loglevel to debug, but it does not spit out anything more. Am I doing something wrong? Can you confirm me the correct syntax?

I will try to see if I can run a debugger in there in the meantime
@carlogrisetti, can you share the config file you used for `in_memory: False`?

sure
[model_definition.yaml.txt](https://github.com/uber/ludwig/files/5490719/model_definition.yaml.txt) EDIT: seems to be in the wrong place!
it's basically the same, with the in_memory: False in the preprocessing section

Oh by the way, it gets stuck exactly [there](https://github.com/uber/ludwig/blob/master/ludwig/features/image_feature.py#L304) even if I specified in_memory False, and I checked the value for in_memory and it is obviously True like it's not being correctly loaded...
Only if I specify in_memory: false under an image: header it gets applied. (is this on purpose? I would suppose that not specifying it for a specific feature type but as a "generic" parameter it would apply to all the feature types that have that parameter available)

BTW, using an in_memory: False in the right place worked like a charm and generated the huge (29GB) hdf5 file.

Oh I almost forgot... once the hdf5 file has been generated, the in_memory: false is not needed anymore, since the issue was only in the hdf5 file generation, and anything else can continue in memory

Hey @carlogrisetti, looks like the config for `in_memory=False` is not specified correctly.  Can you put the preprocessing into the image feature, like this:

```
input_features:
    -
        name: ImageFile
        type: image
        encoder: resnet
        resnet_size: 8
        dropout: 0.05
        preprocessing:
            force_split: false
            in_memory: false
```

@tgaddair See the previous comment... if specified under an image tag (even within the preprocessing) it works as a workaround. I was indeed specifying it as a "global" preprocessing parameter, which I tought Ludwig was designed to manage, but it was not :)

Hey @carlogrisetti, sorry missed that part of the comment.  Glad it worked.  Global preprocessing parameter idea is interesting.  At the least, we want to be able to parse the config file so these sorts of errors are surface up front.

@carlogrisetti and @tgaddair you can actuall yspecify it at a global level, but still on a per feature type basis:
```
preprocessing:
  force_split: false
  image:
    in_memory: false
```

The reason is that `force_split` is a global preprocessing parameter while `in_memory` is image specific. (so Travis' suggestions of putting `in_memory` in the feature preprocessing is correct, but `force_split` should not be placed there, it will have no effect)

The logic is: there are default preprocessing parameters, both global (force_split, split_probablities, etc.) and type specific (image.in_memory, sequence._max_sequence_length etc.). If you specify your custom ones in the preprocessing section, they override them (both global and per type), meaning that if you replace image.in_memory to be False, all image features will behave that way. The local preprocessing you specify for the specific feature will affect only that feature and not the others of the same type. So if you have 3 image inputs for instance, you can set preprocessing.image.in_memory: False to make all 3 read from disk, and if you change the preprocessing of one of them to in_memory True, only that specific one would be loaded in memory.
Hope this clarifies, probably should make it more clear in the docs too.

In conclusion: @carlogrisetti  can you try with the specified global/type preprocessing I pasted and confirm everything works fine and that we can close?
